div.p: A pleasant and witty comedy: called, a new trick to cheat the devil.
London: printed by John Okes, for Humphrey Blunden, and are to be sold at his shop in Cornhill, next to the castle tavern. 1639.

div.head: To the courteous reader, and gentle peruser.
div.p: To make too long an explanation of the worth of the author, or to commend the work with eloquent words, were but to delay the time, and dull thy expectation: it is a comedy which hath been often acted, and so well approved; that I hope none will dislike of it now in the reading: but the poem itself, being now an orphan, and wanting the father which first begotten it, craves a patronage from thy gentle acceptance: my hopes are, it will prove no less pleasing to the reader, than it hath formerly been to the spectators; and so I leave it to thy charitable censure.

div.head: A new trick to cheat the devil.
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Slightall, and mistress Anne.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: May I perish then, if ever thought was
Harboured in this breast,
That did intend you harm;
Your father hath consented you shall be mine;
Your mother still holds off: but having yours,
I care not who withstands;
I am fixed your servant and true lover.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And I thine, in spite of father, mother, kinsfolks,
Friends; thy Anne will never forsake thee.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Then here my dearest, do I plight a vow,
And swear by thy own virtuous grace and sweetness,
By those entrammeled rays, those star-like eyes
Endymion blushes on; those ruby lips,
where a red sea of kisses is divided
By rocks of pearl, by these joined hands, and all things
That have tied my love to thine; I'll never forsake thee.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Slightall, my vow is fixed, no more, my father. Enter changeable.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I have overheard all,
My blessing on you both:
Slightall, I love thee, and am glad thou'st sped;
How I have pleaded for thee, minion, you know.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Father I do, pray you for a while
Conceal it from my mother.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Fear not that wench, how I have laboured with her
You know well, but no consent from her, it is impossible:
What I have stored for thee high heaven does know,
But 'tis my love, which still continues to this wayward girl
Who never could have pleased her father better
Than in this mutual and conjoined assent. Ent. Mrs. changable, and Mr. Treatwell.
Further I would proceed, but see, my wife
Consorted with a stranger.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Sir, here's a gentleman (Slightall so near?)
Desires your conference (No device at all
To shift him hence?) His business craves dispatch,
And is of serious urgence; 'twould become
Your modesty to spare us some few minutes,
Since it no whit concerns you.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: He shall stay, he's now ingraft a scion in our family:
Therefore what us concerns must needs touch him,
Son, son, be constant to your place I charge you.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Remove for no man, now sir speak your mind.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: What in a place so public?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: A place more private would become my message,
And give it gentle hearing.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Pray with draw, it comes from a great man.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Came it from on of the guard, from sir John Falstaff?
Nay, Hercules himself; with bombast limbs
It should have public audience.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Now your big man, name him I pray.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I cry you mercy, my honourable friend, I pray
What service will't please him to command us?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Listen unto't, 'tis all for your preferment.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Fear and doubt perplex me equally.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: The lord my master, to whom the fame of
Your fair daughter's beauty hath thronged by infinite
Tongues, hath in his breast
Took such a strong impression, that he's pleased
(So your consent and his may parallel)
To make her his fair bride.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: You shall be a great lady.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: And take place of all knights wives in the shire.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Sir, I have full commission from his mouth
To treat so much; and what I undertake
He hath engaged his honour to make good.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: His honour? so you shall be honourable,
Be every day caroached; and ride in state.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I wish his lord ship had not sent so late,
My word is passed unto this gentleman;
Which to my power I will not change, nor break
For any King or keisar.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: But you shall sir, and send his lordship satisfaction
Even to his best desire; tell him from me
She shall attend his pleasure: you shall, Nan,
Use him with all obsequious reverence,
And gladly embrace his motion; girl, you shall.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Forward sir, if you withstand the fortune of your daughter
In this tract of preferment without yours.
Send him fair humble language, do my wench
Accept his noble pleasure, and return him
Courteous and loving thanks; think what it is
To be attended, honoured, and advanced.
My lady Anne you shall.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: How poor and slightly mistress Slightall sounds?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Good troth and so it doth.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: But donna Anne, madonna, madam, lady,
What breadth those titles bear?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Mistress? thou shalt have such to be thy servants,
And curtsy to thee when thou turnest thy head;
Bow at each nod, and make their farthingales,
At every word thou speak'st, to kiss their heels.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: What should I say? or how in equal
Balance bear myself?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Footmen, pages, and your gentlemen ushers,
Walk bare before you.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: For all the styles of honour in the world,
I would not break my faith.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Where I was wont to call thee baggage, Nan,
And paltry girl, I must not dare to speak to your
Honour, without a prologue of some half an hour long,
Which must begin, an't please your ladyship.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: 'Tis passing good an't please my ladyship.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Son Slightall, for that title I'll still fasten
Upon thy name, advise me 'What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Methinks the motion might be fair and even,
To make her mistress of her own free thoughts
And choose where she best likes.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: We'll stand to that, let it be put to her.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: In her known love I am so confident,
And of her faith so constantly assured,
So void of all distrust; that I give back
All interest, title, claim, and ceremony
T'attend a second censure. Mistress changeable,
You now are your own woman.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Madam, may it please you take a second choice?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Here's gentry, and here's honour, Mrs. or madam.
A single ambling nag, or a caroche
With four, four great Dutch mares; a private gentlewoman
Or a great lady, my worship, or my honour;
To be a wife to a squire of low degree,
Or a lord baron: gentry shall give place,
And in a puffed style his lordship I'll embrace.
Thus, Slightall, I thy title will outstrip,
That all may say, there goes my ladyship.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: You have your answer Slightall, and good sir,
Return this to my lord.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Sir be my witness, I have no hand in this.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Slightall.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: All come to this? shone the sun bright i'th' morn
To be ere noon enveloped in this cloud?
To be forsook, despised, and disgraced
All for a verbal title? shall I avenge me
On the proud don, or this his changeable stuff?
Whose name and disposition suit so well:
Something I must, but in the interim
Never to fix a constant thought again
Upon that moon-like sex: I'll weigh them all,
Poor, rich, old, young, and middle age alike;
Make no distinction 'twixt the loose and chaste,
The matron and the wanton, women kind;
For the so base inconstancy of one,
Henceforth I'll form myself alike to all:
Licentiousness shall be my mistress now,
Voluptuous pleasure, riot and excess
My future study; I'll let loose desire
And appetite unbridled; and the more
Of that intemperate sex I can corrupt
Count it my greatest deed of charity:
And for thy sake, thou falsest fair; I vow
Affection and all loyal love t'abjure,
Striving to make the clearest streams impure.

div.head: Act. 1. Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter usurer, and his scrivener.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.p: How goes the news o'th' change?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Faith never worse, merchants are wary,
Tradesmen provident, artificers turned frugal, and I think
All the world will prove good husbands.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: Better they, with half a number of that thrifty world
Were three parts hanged; but so much for the city:
What news in Holborn, Fleetstreet, and the strand?
In th'ordinaries among gallants, no young heirs
There to be snapped?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: They've been so bit already
With taking up commodities of brown paper,
Buttons passed fashion, silks, and satins,
Babies, and children's fiddles, with like trash
Took up at a dear rate, and sold for trifles
That now scarce one will bite.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.p: What a world's this? what will't grow to in th'end?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Faith sir heaven knows,
We scriveners fare the worse by't.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: How smart we then?
We money masters, from whose bags you feed,
And without whom your pens would cast no ink?
Nor your wax take impression: none in chase?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Yes, sir, I have one sponge that could you squeeze him,
Would yield good substance.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Yes sir, he hath in acres glebe and meadow,
Upland, and dale, in woods and arable;
And though in name a private gentleman,
Yet hath he three fair lordships, besides sheep-walks,
Parks, and other large demesnes.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: I have dealt closely with a man of his
To undermine him, one that soothes him up
In all his riots, quarrels with his thrifty,
Leads him to game and guzzle in vaulting houses,
and places of bad fame.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: An honest fellow, I'll warrant him;
Can he do ought in this?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: He's one to whom he trusts his whole estate,
And can do all things with him: in these lands
I promised him, if when they were in sail
That I might bring his chapman; a round sum,
To which he seemed to listen.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: 'Twas well scented,
Nor shalt thou lose by't: there's a share for thee;
Acquaint me with the further circumstance,
In which I would be perfect. Enter Roger and Geoffrey, 2. Serving-men.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I do not like this shuffling.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: What Roger, all amort, methinks thou'rt off o'th' hooks?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes faith, and henges too, I'm almost desperate,
And care not how I am.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Faith I was never on a merrier pin,
Nor my breast lighter hearted.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: So, and if thou beest not pleased with that,
Thou must prepare for worse.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Faith scarce with thee, thou art not worth my anger

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: Are we not of one house?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes, but I hope we never shall be of one heart,
My fellow no better than a pander?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes, would that were all, a traitor to that house
Where thou hadst thy first bread, and almost thy being;
Thy making I am sure, but never that poison
That swells so in thy bosom: my good old master,
Heaven rest his soul, uprising, and down lying,
Kept twenty stout tall fellows, whom thy baseness
Hath shrunk to two already; if this riot
To which thou still persuadest the young man hold,
We shall be none, he nothing.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: I could answer thee, but that I spy two gentlemen,
with whom I have business of my masters.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.p: And to me none more welcome.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: All's plotted, we want money, sell we must,
The rate we live at must have fresh supply;
I'll give you the whole project.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Get you together, for a true-love knot
Tied by the devil, may his dam unloose it,
For I shall never: a scrivener, an usurer, and a pimp,
All joined in one, to ruin a young hopeful gentleman.
Now are they turning an old three men's song,
We be knaves all three, mount your notes aloft;
For he that I named last will bear the burden;
A load best fitting him, you'll find him one day
A fellow of excellent carriage, he'll bear with you,
Because he loves you so: so now all's plottedExeunt all three.
And there's a lordship, or a manor at least
Gone at one lift: but what to do with money,
Of which the least is like to come to him
That hath most interest in't; some to the pot,
Part to the pipe, not least share to the smock:
And what remains to gaudify the back,
Must fill the cheater's pocket; o my old master,
Should thy soul see this, it would suffer for't,
As my heart bleeds to think of't. Enter Slightall, and 2. Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.p: But did she break so with you?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Worse than a shopkeeper, that hath
Run long behind hand.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: S'foot , like a puff, a feather â–ª 'tis my lord
Must deal in wholesale with her lady beware,
And I am quite cashiered.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: Troth I commend you, that, so loving her,
You do not take't to heart.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: A heart? at heel; that poor worm, love,
Which some do style a god;
I thus tread underfoot, stamp on his shaft,
and trample on his quiver: I must confess
I once loved beyond thought, but when I saw
My troth so baffled, and my faith despised;
I set it at defiance, and I now
Will be for all, or any.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: What, so general, I pray? is't possible
One that hath loved sincerely, as you say
You once did, should with such an easiness
Change his affection?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I love all fashions, features, forms and faces,
Proportions, sexes, ages, and degrees,
Discretions, wits, disposures, callings, places,
Endowments, faculties, and all alike;
Since one hath failed, I affect all as any, any as one.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: For example, I'll teach thee how to love
The loathedest creature; marry I must turn poetical.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Nay I must be in rhyme too.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Then, thus I do begin;
Dissemble every fault in their complexions.
And take no notice of their imperfections:
Andromeda was belly, sides, and back
To Perseus seen, he did not term her black;
Andromache was of too large a stature,
One loving Hector praised her gifts of nature.
To her whose skin was black as ebon was
I have said ere now, o, 'tis a nutbrown lass.
Or if she looked a squint (As I am true
So Venus looked) if she be bleak of hue;
Pale, for the world, like Pallas; be she grown
By Jove, Minerva up and down.
If she be tall, then for her height commend her,
If she be lean, like envy term her slender.
She that is puffed like Boreas in the cheek,
Is but full fat, and Daphne she is like.
She that is dwarfish, name her light, and quick;
And call her well set, this is grubbed thick.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Is this your lesson? curse upon that tutor
That read you this damned lesson.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: This was Ovid; how approve you these his precepts?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I could instruct you in a thousand such â–ª
And never trouble memory.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: To what the pox, will this your practice bring you?
In these days men do sell their lands, their fortunes,
And their estates to purchase them diseases.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Provide me a good lusty lass tonight ,
I purpose to be merry.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I care not of what humour, face, or feature,
So thou canst find one impudent enough;
Search all the allies, spittle, or Pickt-hatch,
Turnball, the bank side, or the Minories,
White friars, st. Peter's street, and mutton lane,
So thou canst find one to disgrace her sex,
She best shall please my palate,

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: He hath ill taste, that loves to feed on carrion.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Get me likewise a noise of fiddlers, and a supper too,
Equal with that which old Vitellius made,
When art would exceed nature; had I been he
And had his rich exchequer, I would have fed
On nothing but earth's choicest rarities,
Drunk naught but pearl dissolved.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Pray sir a word:
Can this world last ever? you sell, and sell,
But when the money is spent, are you resolved
To feed on husks, and acorns? I am plain,
How many months did your old fathers spend
to purchase that you in few hours consume?
Ha, doth this startle you? I am trusty Roger,
And so you still shall find me: did he compass
That competent estate he left to you
By fiddlers whores, and cheaters? look you big?
Nay sir, I can affront you; where be now
Those furnished tables, whose long backs bid bend
With chines of beef, and chargers, feasting both
Neighbours and strangers? are they
Rioted on lifts and whifflers?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: If none be galled, you have no cause to wince,
But if you be, then figo.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Then do not interrupt me: bawds and whores,
Panders and pimps, did he keep such about him?
I hope none here are touched; call him to mind, sir,
And think upon his worthy memory,
And how you lose yourself.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: My servant's servant? slave, fetch me straight a whore.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: An office fit for none but slaves, I am none;
You had best bid these that are acquainted with them.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: These are gentlemen, my friends, and my companions.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: If they be gentlemen, let them show them such,
That is t'abhor those vices you are wrapped with.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I'll have music, and the choicest cates the city can
Afford, and wine in abundance.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: But some must sure repent it, when all is gone and wasted

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Pox upon you, we shall have you turn Puritan,
Leave big mouthed oaths to swear by yea and nay:
Thou'rt not for me, give me a man can roar,
Show hacks upon his sword, bristle, look big,
Knows all the postures of a true duello;
Give and retort the lie in his full nature:
Can weigh and drink by measure all, or half
To a rundle, or the circuit of a hair,
can weigh his drink as well as measure it,
And,
And without frowns or grumbling still attendEnt. Geffry
On my free humours: Geoffrey, well returned, the news?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: So would my sword had thee.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: A thousand pounds brought in tonight .

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Trifles sir, acknowledging a statute, nothing else;
'Tis finished in a moment.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: And I'll do it; in th'interim go, bespeak us delicates
The best and choicest, the dearer they shall prove
The better they will taste; wenches too, Geoffrey,
Thou knowest my mind, thou seest our number.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Unless thyself wilt make a fourth with us,
And bring (With thee for thine own appetite)
Some courser stuff to keep thee company,
And sit at the buy table.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: It shall be done, I'll be your Mercury.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: If any thing to whet dull appetite,
To heighten pleasure, and inflame delight
Be this night wanting, ere sun rise tomorrow
Cashier me from your service.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Here's a fellow, whose industry doth merit double hire,
Of a free countenance and a light appetite,
When this still frowning grim and surly sir,
Has nothing in his face but melancholy,
And in his tongue repining.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: You'll one day find the difference.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, shall we to cards,
And spend an hour at gleek?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Game too, all will help to send a man a going.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Faith twelve pence if you please.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And so is he too, to be gleeked of all.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: What, will you please to attend us some few hours,
In absence of your fellow?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes, so there be no whores in company,
But rather than feast where they shall domineer,
And bold Rampalian like, swear and drink drunk,
I'll feed on cheese, and onions; and in stead
Of healthing, quench my thirst with frighted water.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I will not haunt him as the devil doth,
But for once I will dog him. Exeunt all.

div.head: Scene. 1.
div.stage: Enter changable, his wife, and Anne.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Unless your wit were grey as well as your hairs;
You grow in years, and so you should in wisdom.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Tax my wit? A woman too, to do't?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Did you never see a bare face teach a beard?
It is no news in this so pregnant age.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: An age indeed, when smocks must read to britches;
Go to wife, thou seekest to make us two that should be one,
Instead of me, thou'rt wedded to thy will;
I fear we shall repent it.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: But I say, ill, ill woman.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Why I pray?
Because I seek the advancement of our house?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I would not build so many storeys high
On such a weak foundation, lest the garret
Reared on such thin supporters sink itself into the cellar.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: One of your gravity? I am ashamed, a justice by
your place, and can appear so partial to your own;
Whom should your providence devise to raise,
If not your own? will you be twice a child?
And now, in this your second infancy,
Not take care for your cradle?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Why then I am no sheep.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: It should be then your care to see me better pleased.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I pray, good mother, nay, sir.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Sir me no sirs, I am no knight nor churchman,
There is a third, make me not that by breaking of my faith.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Think what it is to have a great lord call you
Father in law, and so your daughter a great lady.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: So; I had rather see her a good gentlewoman,
Lawfully great in belly and in purse,
Than swelled with poisoned titles; it to me
Appears no better than a timpany,
A grief not easily cured.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: His lordship will be here, give him good face,
And courteous language, or I'll make your board
As loud as a perpetual gossip's feast,
Or a discourse of fishwives; and your bed
As if you were to lodge in Lothbury
Where they turn brazen candlesticks.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: So you are like to find it.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Gentle wife, have patience, and be quiet, I'll give way;
I never hear thy tongue in this high key,
But I still think of the tower ordnance,
Or of the peal of chambers, that's still fired
When my lord Major takes barge, I will do any thing,
Good wife please thyself, and I am contented.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Why well then: might not this time much better
Have been spent, to have taught your daughter rudiments
Of state? her postures, and decorums, fine French congees,
And quaint outlandish garbs? one that hath been
A courtier in his youth, and brought naught thence?
Fie, fie; I am ashamed of't.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Look to the gate there; methought I heard one knock.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And comes, it seems, to see my ladyship;
I feel state come upon me; speak good mother,
How shall I bear myself?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Why such at first, as you must be hereafter; like a lady.
Proud, but not too perverse; coy, not disdainful;
Strange, but yet not too straight; like one that would,
Were she well wooed, but yet not to be won,
Without some formal courtship; had it been
My case, my wench, when I was young like thee,Enter lord Treatwell.
I could have born it bravely. See, he's come,
Husband, your duty; girl, your modest blush,
Mixed with a kind of strange, but loving welcome;
Were I as young as once: your lordship sir,
Hath done my house much honour.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Your mother sir, that must be.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I make bold,
And like a rude intruder, press upon you
Sudden, and unawares.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Sir, I desire your more familiar love,
Whom I shall study hereafter to respect
According to your worth and gravity.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: You crave his love whose service you command.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I have seen a thousand private gentlemen
Both better faced and featured.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Mrs. Anne, for so your name was given me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Nay kiss better,
Besides, he hath the mark of an ill liver,
He hath not a nose strong enough.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: You see sir, what homely entertainment,
And how course our poor house can afford you.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Were it base,
But 'tis much better than I yet deserve,
That face alone would make and dignify't;
your welcome I approve, good sir, a word:
Nay, master Treatwell, you may witness it,
We do not trade in secrets.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Troth I felt no more honour from his lips
Than from another man, nay scarce so much;
For Slightall kisses better.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I tell you as I find; his lordship? good now
Tell me, in what place of his body lies it?
If in the face or foot, the crown or toe,
The body, arm, or leg, the back, or bosom,
Without him, or within? I see no more
In him than in another gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Part of it lies in what he left behind,
Observance, state, retinue, and attendance,
Of which you must partake.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Lord, who'd have thought it?
Would he had sent that part of his lordship hither,
And stayed himself behind; but where's his honour?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Dost thou not see him there?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: How cast thou fool? his nobility lies in his blood,

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Yes, if his lordship live in that â–ª
Would you match me to a thing invisible?
Where I bestow myself I'll see and feel,
And choose to my own liking.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: So you would make me; this is but a man,
And I can find a man to my own liking and never trouble him.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: This foolish baggage will cross all we would compass.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I am plain sir;
I have not much to give, yet I would stretch
My utmost, to my poor ability,
To show myself a father, what she wants
In means she hath in gentry; that my blood
Can witness for her: something too besides
Though not sufficient to ennoble her,
Yet still to make her a good gentlewoman,
And that's all my ambition.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: And that's all I can demand.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Provided still, all be with her consent,
For I'll force nothing, were't from a stranger,
Much less from my child.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: There's no condition you have yet proposed
But warrants grant, they are so reasonable.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Till now I had thought, your lords, and noble men
Had been possessed of many worthier parts,
Where meaner men are scanted; but I see
All's one, or little difference.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Mistress Anne, it were superfluous to begin a suit
Which hath before been entered; and I know
Made known to you ere this; I come not now
For motion, but for answer: all those honours
Titles, and dignities conferred on me
We likewise do communicate with you.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Which she is ready to accept.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Good mother, 'tis me, not you, whom this affair concerns:
You gave your own free answer to my father,
So give me leave to do where I affect,
The good or bad is mine; not touches you
That are disposed already.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: My good wench, I do commend thee for't.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: No more wife, I have done.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Or I shall but begin. My lord, proceed.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Court ladies I have often seen and tried,
Fair country damsels, virgins of choice beauty,
bred from the city scarlet, and among these
I might have made my choice, but all relinquished
To place affection here; what comfort â–ª lady?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Faith little in that name:
Title my lord, is a cold bedfellow,
And many study style that marry cares;
Can honour help in childbirth? or nobility
Us privilege from throws?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Why ceremony;
The gift of princes, and the pride of states,
Regard in the weal public, and employment â–ª
Respect, and duty.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Which from his pre-eminence
Must by mere consequence redound to you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You talk like an old woman, not like one
That should make her first choice, as I must now;
When I am grieved, can honour cure my heart?
If discontent, can my nobility
Give ease unto my corrosives? when your lordship
Is with your trulls and concubines abroad,
Where is my loving husband then at home
To keep me warm at midnight?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, that's the thing I doubt.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Could you not lend your lordship to a friend,
And keep the man yourself?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To a poor gentleman, one master Slightall,
Who, had he but that slight addition,
I gladly would embrace.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Therefore to show me serious, noble man,
I take my leave thus gently.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: That's no answer; why Nan, why minion, good your
Lordship, take naught in ill part; a peevish thing,
God wot, that wants a little tutoring.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Slightall quoth 'a? if she slight all as she hath slighted me,
She'll fright hence all her suitors.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Still will you prate? wil't please your honour, take
Such cheer as this our suddenness affords?
And there's no question but ere dinner's done
This tempest will blow over.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I'll take your kindness,
He's no good soldier that at first repulse
Will leave the breach; belike she's fasting now,
I'll take her in full stomach.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Please you enter?
Attendance for his lordship. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. 2. Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter usurer, and scrivener, with writings.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: As fast as wax and witness can make good.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: Yes, and as great an use as e'er you lent out money on.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.p: Is there no hope he will redeem't at all?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Redeem this did you say? tush, had he more,
More he would soon send after; why he's all expense and riot.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: I shall love expense and riot while I live;
Not in myself, I must confess, but in such prodigals
By whom we usurers profit.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: So let him, what he hath;
But this I'll look to safe as my life.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: He minds nor cares for nothing.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.p: For this he minds not, my care is taken already.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: Troth he's sinking, he's up to the neck already.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.p: May he drown for him that holds him by the chin.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Alas poor sheep, each bramble shares his wool.
Till he be fleeced quite.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: What makes he then 'mongst briers? this be his comfort,
His flesh will show the better when he's shorn,
He'll make sale for the shambles.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: O these dice, drabs, and drink?

sp.speaker: Usurer
sp.l: Excellent sokers, brave pills to purge the purse:
But for my part, I will take no such physic.

sp.speaker: Usurer
sp.l: Marry, first home, and safely lock up these,
Then seek some other new come to his lands,
To make like prey on him.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: I am your scrivener, and sir, I hope
You'll not forget my pains?

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: Forget thee? no, not whilst thy parchment lasts:
I do remember thee by thy shop, thy sign,
Yes, thou hast labels hanging at thy door;
Thou writest a good fair hand, and hast in horn,
Six several seals with sundry strange inscripts
All joined together; thee? not remember thee?
I can call thee by thy name.

sp.speaker: Usurer
sp.l: Money from me, thy writings are all paid for,
It came from Slightall's purse.

sp.speaker: Usurer
sp.l: Brokage indeed hath some dependence still
On usury, and usury on that,
They're relatives; one is not called a son
That hath no father, and no father's he
That hath no son; yet money doth go hard.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: Yet let me have my due.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: Yes, give the devil that,
For he will have't at length; ha, let me see,
Come, let us once be mad, we'll to the next tavern,
And there debate the business.

sp.speaker: Usurer
sp.p: Yes, for this once, not use't.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: A gallon sir, betwixt us two?

sp.speaker: Usurer
sp.l: An usurer's gallon, that's just half a pint,
'tis none of Slightall's measure, 'tis too great,
And come, good scrivener, write it in record,
That I am now thus liberal.

div.head: Act 2. Scaen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Slightall, Roger, and Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: You have served me long, what have you got by me?

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Good wine, good victuals, liveries;
And the countenance of a good master.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: That's as your worship shall be pleased to call it.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: So please you sir, I shall;
That which I think you're brought to now yourself,
Or within little of't.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Thy plains I commend, thee and thy wit,
That canst give nothing name, such is my state;
Yet out of this confused lump of naught,
That which no man of sense can say it is,
Or title by the name of any thing,
Something I have extracted, and reserved
For you, for you my servants; take this gold.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Why, all this alas is nothing.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: To me it is not, for now it is yours,
And may it ever after something prove
To you and your succession, as a stock
To thrive and prosper by; I only was,
But am not now; however be you still,
And may this give you essence.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Pray keep mine,
Your service sir is all the heritage that I expect from you.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Thou never wast one that did seek to husband my estate,
Which I have vainly wasted; just, and honest,
In all my loose designs didst counsel well,
and still persuadest me to providence,
That thrift of which I was uncapable,
Employ it to thy own ends; had it been more,
Greater had been thy stock.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I'll keep it sir, as steward to your use, but
Always ready to furnish your least wants.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Though thou wast ever pander to my lusts,
And gavest me spurs to all my vanities,
Fed'st on my riots, and my loose excess,
Encouragest still to surfeits, praydest not for me
But still preyest on me Geoffrey; yet, because
Thou once didst claim dependence on my love,
And didst me some slight service; still report
Thou hadst a bounteous master; so farewell both.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: If this he all, as where no more is left
What more can be expected? this's my portion,
I'll husband't for myself; he that gets this,
Or part of this, must have more share in me
Than either man or master.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Adieu good fellows, report you've left a clean
Gentleman, without or means, or money.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: And my neglect; so I be stored myself,
Which hand with him goes forward.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: A woman; that inconstant feminine sex,Exit Rog. and Geffry.
That changes humours oftener than the moon
Wanes, or supplies his orb: that moving creature
Hath been my quick subversion:
Had she proved firm; for her I had husbanded
All that I now have lavished; but too late,
What shall I now do! travel? who shall furnish me?
What comfort can there be to beg abroad?
Or make myself a storm to foreign nations,
After I too much have been tossed at home?
I'll prove my kindred; kindred he hath none
That hath not in his purse to rank with them.
My kindred wasted, as I spent my means,
want makes me a mere stranger: than my friends,
There's no such name for him whom need compels
To such extremes as I am newly fallen:
Relief from them, such as in cakes of ice
To him, whose nerves and arteries are shrunk up
By bitter winter's fury: then behold,
I here expose me to the fate, and force
Of all disasters threaten me; I am ready
With a pinched stomach, and cold Arctos breath,
With a bare breast, armed with patience
Against the sharpest storm, and thin necessity;
T'encounter with the keen and piercing fangs
Of what want can inflict on my poor carcase.

div.stage: Enter Anne

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Let father frown, or movingly entreat,
My mother chide, or threaten menaces,
Rail till her tongue, that yet was never tired,
Cleave to her roof in midst of her exclaims:
Let my spruce lord cog in his courtly terms,
And woe me with a thousand vain protests;
Not all my father's hate, my mother's fury,
Nor all his alphabet of styles and names,
Could they a sheepskin fill, shall me divert
From that which I have vowed, to seek him out
And prostrate my first love.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: The devil, he
My mind suggests when all my means else fail;
That bugbear will supply me.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I am not yet provided friend, not yet;
Thou takest me on a sudden.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: For a she-devil; but I meant not her,
My business lies with him that's lord and captain
Of all the fiends and firebrands; haunt me not,
Thou canst do me no pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: There can be no more terror in his look
than in the face of my extreme distress:
His visage cannot be so horrible
As my despair; what should I fear then, ha?
An usurer may wear horns, a scrivener too,
Should I be more afraid of his then theirs?
I know no reason for't.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Man can no sooner think upon the devil,
But a woman is at's elbow; trust me not
I've no affairs with thee.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Leave those vain thoughts
As fantasies of a distracted brain;
I come with sorrow, and repentant tears;
To bring you back your own.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Not possible,
That's all in hucksters handling, and canst thou
Bring it from thence? why the great devil himself
Can never do't; some is distributed
Among bawds, and whores; here panders have a part,
And cheaters there a share; taverns, and ordinaries:
But the prime part the usurer hath in's chest,
I would 'twere in his belly: and the choice
Of all I had, for which these were reserved,
Prized by me but as trivial ornaments
T'adorn one jewel, rated above them,
Higher than gold above the basest dross,
And that the lord hath seized.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Lord of this soil; which I will never repurchase
After his so base sullying.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: What says my donna Anne, my lady serpent
Armed in her golden scales? What says Madona?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: That I prefer thy basest poverty
Before all glorious titles; give me ear,
And I'll redeem thy former injuries
With ample satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Hear me first;
Back to your lord, and if you want reparations,
first fall into his hands.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: It was my folly,
My appetite too childish novelty,
Of which I now crave pardon.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: O woman, woman,
Thou hast undone me, spent me to my shirt,
Nay beyond that, even almost to my soul;
For I am circled in with black despair,
And know not how to free me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I can do't,
And to that end I come; wants thy soul comfort?
Behold, I bring you comfort: is your state
Decayed and wasted? see, I offer thee
A second making, all my hopes and fortunes,
I throw on thee; I am possessed of nothing
Of which thou art not lord.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Lord? there it goes;
And get thee to him, for in rifling thee
He hath robbed my brain of sense, my life of means,
My soul of solace, and my days of rest;
Henceforth I'll be a madman, turn as savage
As thou to me was't brutish: I'll seek out
Some fine familiar devil, and with him
Converse, when I have left man's company;
I'll make myself companion with the night,
And traffic with her servants like the owl;
I'll take my lodging in some hollow cave,
Till I be grown so out of name and knowledge,
That if I chance but to appear by day,
Men, beasts, and birds shall all stand wondering at me;
As at some prodigy, and point at thee
For this my transformation.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Jealousy, o what a fury art thou?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Fury, where? kept it within my bosom I would cherish it,
And hug't as one that I accounted most:
Lay't in this hand I'd brandish't 'gainst my stars
And dare them to encounter: lodged it here,
Within my eyes, I would outstare the devil,
the devil, I the devil.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: That foul fiend,
Why do you name so oft? o study better thoughts,
And set him at defiance.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Canst not endure his name, yet comest thyself
To tempt me with his satin? o those eyes,
That once appeared like to those glorious tapers
That spangle heaven, show like black funerals
The sisters bear, that blast where ere they burn:
Farewell my ruin, my decay and fall,
And what sinister fate soe'er I have.
May thy false pride b'insculped upon my grave. Exit.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Curse on that pride, that such a hopeful gentleman
Should in his prime be lost by that and me;
But who was cause? who first traduced me to't?
My mother, and that lord; the sin be theirs:
Offend they, and must scape due punishment?
Then let me lose, what womankind best arms,
My use of tongue; if but this pipe hold clear,
I'll make both curse them taught me first to speak,
And wish I from my cradle had been dumb:
My hate to him shall in his charge and cost,
Redeem the love that I to this have lost. Exit.

div.head: Scene. 1.
div.stage: Enter old friar Bernard, and young friar John.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Now we have passed our more retired hours
To holy uses as our vows compel;
In zealous and religious exercises,
In visitation of the weak and sick,
To strengthen those that stagger with our prayers,
And ghostly counsel; now night calls us home
Unto our cloister, there to spend the rest
Of our late hours in thoughts contemplative,
and sacred meditations.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Holy father, I am afraid time hath prevented us,
'Tis now passed eight, and, but I much mistake,
I heard the warning of the cloister bell,
Which tells us, if we reach not instantly
We're for this night excluded.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Mercy heaven how swift time runs?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: We're now at Islington,
What hope have we to get to crutched friars
Before the gates be shut, and the keys carried
Up to the abbot's chamber?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Thou say'st true, how shall we spend the night then?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: We'll knock here
At the next sign, the good man I know well,
Of honest conversation, of good life,
And yet a boon companion; one that loves
Good company, and to be merry with them.
He, if he be at home, will bid us welcome:
My hostess too, a sweet and smooth-faced wench,
Courteous and kind, and wondrous well beloved
Of all her neighbours; liberal to the church,
And much commended for her charity.
Let us not balk her house.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Knock good friar John, and beg us a night's lodging.

div.stage: Enter woman.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: For charity those that would be admitted.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Charity should be in bed at midnight.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: But devotion should always wake;
Where's the good man your husband?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: He's gone from home, and that's a reason too
We shut up doors thus early; say, what are you?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Religious men, and keep unlawful hours?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Tis no vain pleasure,
Or evil purpose that hath kept us out,
But Christian zeal to visit and confirm
Them, for his sake to whom our lives are vowed;
grant us relief and harbour.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: 'Twere suspicious for me, but a lone woman, he abroad,
To entertain men of your rank and place,
Whose lusts have all been questioned, and have drawn
Good women of best rumour and report,
Into foul scandal; therefore pardon me,
This night you get no entrance.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My good dame,
You see me aged, and far spent in years,
Decrepit, and unfit for dalliance,
And should my youthful novice strive to exceed
His lawful bounds, I am near to counsel him,
But he was never guilty of such thoughts.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Alas my kind dame, not I.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Then grant us the least shelter, any place,
By or remote, to keep us from the cold;
Stable, or barn, if you be so provided,
Or any out room where's but hay, or straw
To wrap us in till morning.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Can you be so hard-hearted unto men
Of our so known devotion?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Grant us this, and you shall have the assistance of our prayers
In all our trentals, masses, dirges, orisons,
Your soul shall be remembered; but if we
Should by your rude remorceless cruelty
Miscarry in our persons, in this raw
And so bleak cold; the price of our two lives
Must be of you exacted.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Curse upon them,
No night but this to trouble me in? being engaged
To better fare by appointment.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Gentle dame, for reverence of my years and gravity,
And for my covents order; for my name
And my profession, grant friar Bernard this
Harbour from frost and snow.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Well friar, you shall,
But this provided, I will lock you up
in a close garret, and myself keep the key
To avoid suspicion; you shall have fresh straw,
But other bedding none, no fire nor candle,
Beer, ale, nor any such commodity,
Now in my husband's absence; so, pray enter,
And this I do for charity.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Now heaven's benison fall on thy head, that two
Religious men art so obsequious; gentle novice, be
Civil and much observant, 'tis a courtesy
We scarce can find else where.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: My holy father,
I know it well; I am prescribed my limits,
Which I am willing with all zeal t'observe;
I would we knew our lodging.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: All necessities are ever to be pardoned, once, like horses,
Let's lodge in our own litter; I commend
The woman's modesty, that is so curious,
Her husband being from home, to avoid scandal,
And men's base imputations.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: So do I,
'Tis one of our best dames; but see, she comes
To give us entertainmentEnter the woman.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: I have only a cock-loft, please you gentle friars,
To make best use of that and some fresh straw,
Best harbour that my husband's absence yields
You're welcome to.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: We entertain it gladly,
And thank you my good dame, I am for sleep,
That's this my night's ambition.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Please you enter, but yet no further than I'll lock you in
I'll keep the key myself.

div.stage: Enter constable, with a bottle of wine, and manchets.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: My watch is set, charge given, and all at peace,
But by the burning of the candle blew,
Which I by chance espied through the lantern,
and by the dropping of the beadle's nose,
I smell a frost; now to prevent this cold,
To which I am subject, I have made my deputy,
Given up my staff and power into his hands;
Myself intending to spend all this night
Here, at an honest neighbours; some provision
I have sent in, and some I have brought along,
A cast of manchets, and a bottle to
Of the best wine in Turnball, which, they say
All London cannot better: silent all,
None stirring near, I'll knock but softly for fear
Of waking neighbours.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Not too loud, mean time I softly will sneak down
The stairs, and softly let you in.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Gramercy wench; the kindest loving neighbour the
Town yields, the hamlet cannot match her; a smug lass,
And one that knows it too; I would not lose her
For half my state in the parish, while I'm in office,
She's safe as mouse in mill: o, are you come?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: I was in fear you would have broke with me,
But now I see you're currant.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Sweet a kiss, and hark in thine ear. Friar John peeps out above.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Friar Bernard's fast, he snores and sleeps as
Snug as any pig in peas-straw; but myself
Cannot once close an eye, which makes me wonder
That I am grow so wakeful.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Here's to thy good fat pullet that's within,
Two fine cheat loaves were sent me from the court,
A cup of nipsitate brisk and neat;
The drawers call it tickle-brain, 'twill do't,
But is the roast-meat ready?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Piping hot, I'll go fetch salt and trenchers.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Dream I? or is't substantial that I see?
Was this your cunning dame, to lock us up
like prisoners, and afford us naught but straw
To feather our nests withal? not allow us drink,
Food, nor a candle, lest we should fire the house,
For that is her excuse; fire on you both,
Have you these tricks? yet God a mercy cranny
That I can spy all this. She brings in the pullet.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Now let's be merry, but in any case
Speak not too loud, lest we should wake the friars.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Two abbey lubbers that are locked up fast,
Of whom I could not rid me; but I think
I have fitted them, they have neither light nor bed,
Nor any other comfort.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Tush, no matter,
What's that to us? Come sweet, cut up the pullet,
And after we'll to bed.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Do you't, I am no carver.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Do you strain courtesies? had I it in fingering
I'd make you both make but a Fridayes feast;
O how the steam perfumes my nostrils.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: In faith it shall be thine.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: If I begin, may I never eat more.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Here's a third would do't, knew he but how to come by't.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Well, since you'll force me to't,
I will make bold this once. One knocks at the door.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: If that should be my husband?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: You were shamed, I quite undone; he knocks again;
Upon my life 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: What shall become of me?
Dost thou not think he'll spare an officer?
But fall on the King's image?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Now to convey these victuals hence, and put out the fire,
Lord husband is it you? who looked for you so late?
These shall into the cupboard, if the smell
Betray's not we're safe.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Ay, if my swell betray me not.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: I have got such a cold, a cough withal,
I thought I should have died; stay but a little
Till I have cast my petticoat about me,
I'll quickly let you in; the fire's quite out,
No sign of any feast.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: I'm almost starved, prithee make haste.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: I am coming, good lie close, and if I can get him
Once to bed, I have a trick to shift you.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: I do feel I had need of shift already.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Here's brave juggling?
For this night, constable, I am your watch;
O but the smoking pullet. Enter host, and hostess.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Lord husband that you'll venture whom so late,
So many knaves abroad?

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: I fear no robbing, and for my carcase, I still bear
About me to defend that, I've travelled hard today,
And am very hungry prithee wife see what thou hast in the house?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: What, talk of victuals now? is this a time of night?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: I by my faith, for one that could come by't.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Talk not to me, something I must and will have.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Had I known
But of your coming home I had provided,
But now I pray to bed, this cold so troubles me.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Cold troubles me, lay me some faggots on.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: You see the fire's quite out.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Would house and all were fired,
So some of us were out on't.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: I would have had some company, I had not
such an appetite to be merry for an hour this seven year;
That I could tell where to call up some good fellow
That I knew, we would not part these two hours.

div.stage: Friar John makes a noise in the garret.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Now bless us wife, what noise is in the garret?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: No hurt man; nay, pray will you to bed?

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Bed me no beds, I'll know the reason of't.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Two friars shut from their covents, wanting harbour,
Begged lodging with such importunity
They would not be denied; at length I pitied them,
And yet to make them sure, I locked them fast
Up in the straw-loft, and see, here's the key,
They're fast enough for starting.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Friar Bernard, and friar John? th'only good lads
That I desired to meet with; I beshrew thee
They had no better welcome; go, unlock,
Entreat them hither, we will have one cup
To th'health of all their covent.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Call them up? what time shall we to bed then?

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Time enough, early betimes, nay, quick Nan, friar John there?
The bonniest lad e'er wore portace in a string,
Or mumbled mass, or matins; I but wished
And see, 'tis come to pass; the other to,
Though he be strict of life, yet will sometimes
Be merry, if he like his company;
But my kind honest baldpate, friar Jack,Enter woman and friars.
I shall be glad to see him; welcome faith,
With reverence, father, to your gravity,
Be not offended if friar John and I
Be, not exceeding compass, a little merry,
And play with the pot; fill some in.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: To your bellies pots and all.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Excess, my host, can purchase no excuse,
But modest mirth, transgressing not his true
And lawful bounds, is good and commendable;
now give us leave to bid you welcome home.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Thanks good friar Bernard,
Now as I live, would I had some good cheer,
No better than I would pay for; but she tells me
There's nothing to be compassed.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: The worse luck; and yet I smell a supper.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Not so much as a cantle of cheese, or crust of bread,
That can this night be come by (For your throats,
I'll rather see you choked.)

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: But any fare that would content the stomach.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Say you so? I'll try what I can do.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: What a leering eye the friar cast towards the cupboard?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Bid my dame provide cloth, salt, and trenchers.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: But friar John, how shall we come by meat?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: For such provision trust to my art.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: By art, can that be done?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O profane, and fearful!
Art magic! didst thou ever study that?
It is against our order.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: But not as I will order it, fear it not.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: For a supper, or so, but never durst deal further;
Will you furnish a table fit for meat?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: We shall have now some fooling.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Good father peace, no hurt to you nor me.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: That's furnished with a stomach.
Doemones, et cacodoemones conjuro vos, surgite et venite.
No man stir, is the cloth laid, and all things fit for meat?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: You see to please you, we can do any thing.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Now let me see,
What Christian climate yields us the best bread?
O, the best wheat's in Spain; what say you now
To a couple of cheat loves baked in Madrid,
And brought into this chamber?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: All vostro commando, Asterothe, ill pane in hac camera presto.
O, now 'tis done; mine host, put but your hand
Into that corner and pull forth two loaves.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: But see what art can do.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Pox on the friar, have you these tricks?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: The best in Spain, or friar John much mistakes:
Place them good mine host, behind the salt.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Peace father, more will be done anon;
What climate yields the best French grape?
My spirit whispers Orleans grape's the best,
What says mine host to a pure cup of Orleans?

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Faith I say, would I might see't.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Je vou pre monsieur Asterothe, once more
A cup of divine claret; no, a bottle of some two quarts â–ª
Gramercy, thou hast done't, mine host, but cast your eye
Upon that place, and you shall find it there.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Most admirable, see, here's a bottle full.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: But taste mine host, and try if it be right.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Your devils take you; you know where's the best liquor.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Excellent stuff, I never drank better claret.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: No hurt to you still, father.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Bread and drink? how shall we come by meat?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Let me see, there is a midnight supper now served in
At Prague in Germany, where the emperor's court
Lies for the most part, and seldom is he absent;
Among all all other dainties, speak, what dish
Desire you from the table?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What say you to a pullet piping hot,
Now standing on the dresser?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: The devil take all such smell-feasts.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: But once more I'll employ thee, Asterothe,
For this night no more trouble thee. Veni, assist,
And in hac re succurre; I smell the pullet
Smoking, and sauce unto't.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Somewhere about this room, who hath the key
Of that same cupboard?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Call for it, good mine host,
You see I come near nothing, use fair play,
Saw neither fire nor candle to provide this,
Touched neither lock nor key within your house,
But was asleep i'th' straw; unlock mine host,
See what the cupboard yields.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: A poison on thee, would it might prove so to thee,
It was never provided for those chops.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What find you there?

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: A hot fat pullet, newly dressed and sauced.
I never heard the like,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: You see what art can do.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Tell me, friar John?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I'll talk with you anon, in the mean time
Eat while 'tis hot, 't hath come a pretty journey,
And marvel 'tis not cold.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Good wine, good bread, good victuals, stomach good,
And all to meet together? nay fall to,
And he be thanked that sent it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: This to me appears beyond imagination,
Nay, gentle hostess sit.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Many provide good cates that taste them not,
Now blessing on their hearts.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: But curse on thine, and on thy stomach too.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: I pray friar John, what spirit do you deal with?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Aestroth, did you not hear me name him?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: One of the four great spirits, that have dominion
O'er the four quarters of the earth: good dame,
Methinks you do not eat.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Could you not show your devil for a need,
to one that fain would see him?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: O 'tis too terrible, it would fright us all.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What, in his terrors? he would make you mad,
Distracted and amazed, yet, good mine host,
To give you all content, I could be willing
To show him but in some familiar shape,
Such as should not affright you.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Have you no neighbour whom you best affect, whose
Shape he might assume t'appear less terrible?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Soft, let me pause;
It must be some that still wake at these hours,
We have no power o'er sleepers; say I bring him
In person of some watchman?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Or in the habit of your constable?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: More scurvy tricks friar John, I may live to cry quittance with you.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: But mine host, resolve me one thing; should great
Asterothe appear to you in your gossip's shape,
How would you deal with him?

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Why as my friend, my neighbour, and my gossip.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: No such thing; you must imagine him what he appears,
An evil spirit, to kick him, and defy him,
As you would do the devil, otherwise
When you are late abroad, and we gone hence,
He'll haunt your house hereafter.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Fear not that,
If kicks and spurns will drive the devil hence,
I'll help to send him packing.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I must tell you, 'tis merely for your own good,
Appear Asteroth, Asteroth appear from underneath the bed
In shape of master Constable; do't when I say't, not yet?
Excruciabo te Asteroth, in jam jam jam apparebis.
Now mine host, either with zeal expel the devil hence,
Or have your house still haunted.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Will kicks do't?
Let me alone to conjure him, pox on the devil,
He hath put me in a sweat.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: I'll after him â–ª and lest he should bear down part
Of the house, I'll let him out of doors.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Yes, do good Nan; I think friar John
I have bombasted the devil; thanks for our supper,
French wine, and Spanish loaves, I never tasted meat
That more contented me.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I'll tell you by the way; no questions now:
Now good mine host we see the night quite spent
And the bright day star rising in the East;
We'll take our leaves; make much of our good dame,
And think no worse of your good officer,
Your gossip and your neighbour, in whose form
Asteroth so late appeared.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Good night friar John, and holy father Bernard.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Only commend us to my dame your wife,
And thank her for our lodging.Exeunt

div.head: Act. 3. Scaen. 2
div.stage: Enter lord Skales, Treatwell, Roger, and Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: 'Tis most true, you never saw a man so strange debauched;
He hath not only run out all his fortune,
But even his senses; I had once my lord,
Some small dependence on him, but his riot
Hath almost ruined me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Thou shalt have't
See, master Treatwell, that his name b'enrolled
Among my other servants; let my steward
receive such notice from you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Preferred already? may I live to see thee
Advanced some few steps higher, to the gallows.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Yes, one that he did never, nor I think never will,
Yet a lord too.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I thank you, no; were there no other masters
On the earth, I am no man for you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Because the last I had, I lost by you, a man, that
Save his title, bettered you, or any of your blood.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Long you to have your teeth picked? I'll find time
To talk with you hereafter.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: A bold fellow; give him scope, my lord.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: He was a gentleman descended well,
As ancient as yourself, as well endowed
With all the gifts of nature; better tutored,
For he could write true scholar, which few lords
In these days practise; not ambitious,
Nor yet base thoughted, for he kept the mean,
And aimed but at his equal; you in this
Come short of; for you, less noble breasted,
Have stooped to your inferior.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Nay good my lord have patience; hear him speak.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Think you, you could have bettered him in valour?
He was too full of fire, witness his spirit,
Most worthy of a Roman character;
That being oppressed, and only crossed in her,
He lost himself in all things; and shall I
Serve him, by whom a graft of his fair hope
Is by his whale-like title swallowed up?
And feed at his board that hath famished him
That was my master? let such sycophants do't,
That to their lords affections suit their service,
not to their fames and honours: that can fawn,
Lie, cog, and flatter, pimp, and pandarize,
And so farewell, good fellow.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: I speak sir of my fellow, he's now none
For he attends your lordship.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: This fellow's bluntness
Doth somewhat better than at first,
Whom wilt thou follow now?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Him, to his grave, or to his better fortunes;
Bless your lordship. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: I do not think but under that rough brow
Is lodged an honest heart; they are best servants
Whom want, penurious need, and poverty
Cannot fright from their masters. Ent. Chan. and his wife.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: O master changeable, how is't with your daughter?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Peace you, all will be well, I hope; yet peevish, but
It will bring pliantness: 'tis coming on a pace.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: You hear that news of m. Slightall's frenzy, and his undoing?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: And yet your wisdom would have matched your
Daughter unto that spendthrift beggar.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: This his servant, since entertained by me hath told me all.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Use you your humours,
And jest at his distress; but when I think
What he hath been of late, what come to now,
I cannot choose but sorrow; and the more
When I record the ground of his distress;
But my soul's clear of all. Enter Anne.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I am as cold as ice, and you a scold.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And thou a slave and pander.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: Speak it not, I'll not believe it mistress.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Faith mother a mad wench, I thank my stars.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: But mistress changeable, why did you call me these?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Stand but in row, and as I am a woman
I'll make all this good; you here, you there,
And every one in order: first, in particular,
And next in general I will go over you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: A noble thief, that was your character,
Some by the high way rob; some are sea thieves,
We commonly call 'em pirates; some break houses,
And others snap at stalls; some cunningly
Dive into pockets, whistlers, others lifts;
Some are poetical thieves, and steal by wit,
One from another plots, and projects, cheats,
And decoys; but all these under thieves,
And steal but petty trash: but you more great,
Under pretext of your nobility,
And countenance in court, have from a husband
Stolen a contracted and a married wife;
For contract upon earth, in heaven is marriage;
And celebrate by angels.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: A gentle fool, such are your patient husbands,
That yield their wives the breeches.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Is he such? how now bold housewife, baggage, peevish
Thing, rude, disobedient, apish, and perverse,
Irregular, hare brained, harsh and obstinate?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You see, she need not put me to my proof,
Her tongue will do't itself.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I pray your name? Tre. Treatwell.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Take but the two first letters from your name,
I take't, 'tis Eat-well.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: But all this mistress, makes not me a pander.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: No, but when thou first was't base bawd to the riots
Of thy first master, thou madest thyself such.
But now in general let me see;
The prince is not without his flatterer,
The noble man his secretary,
The lawyer his attorney,
The justice his clerk,
The physician his apothecary,
The usurer his scrivener,
The extortioner his broker,
Nor the lady cannot be without her gentleman usher;
Your citizen's wife her journeyman,
Your country wench her sweetheart,
Your tobacco woman her pipe-maker,
And every whore her pander.
Farewell Geoffrey; God be with you gentlefolks. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Nay good sir spare your tears,
She hath hit us all alike; this her ingeniousness
Adds to her beauty, not detracts at all;
I love her never the worse, nor any here
Whom her discourse hath touched: 'tis witty frenzy,
And no malicious canker; so I take it:
Nay grieve not you good woman, whom ere long
I hope to title mother; doubt it not, all shall be well.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Let not that stick in thy stomach, never couldst thou
Light on a more fair and sweet godmother,
To give thee a name; I'll have all friends, let's in,
And comfort the sad gentleman, and after to supper.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Where I'll try how near of kin I am to this
Gentleman, and show myself an Eat-well. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene. 1.
div.stage: Enter Slightall melancholy.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: A pistol, poniard, poison, or a cord,
The least of these would do't; nay, my own want
had I the patience but to stay,
The time would end me, for since charity late is dead,
How can beggars live? Death is the easiest
Of any thing on earth for man to compass;
Almost no object but doth offer it:
Fire, water, not a stone we stumble at;
Our very meat and drink but surfeit of't,
It would dispatch one quickly: I have read
Of one choked with a fly; another drinking,
Strangled with the berry of a bruised grape,
Another with an hair; what's this life than
We men do make so much of? if a pin,
A very hair hath power to take it hence?
Cursed fall of man, in whose first disobedience
All things on earth rebelled, and war with him:
How many thousand things hath fate ordained
To stop weak nature's course? and among them,
How few which can preserve it? which apprehension
Makes me that now I more desire to live,
The more my life's opposed: if there be devils,
As all religion tells us, I desire
To have converse and conference with some one
The greatest fiend among them, for by him
My genius prompts me, either I shall raise
My ruined hopes, revenge me on my foes,
Or end my wretched days in this despair.
I could turn sorcerer, witch, or any thing
Might I but blast her beauty, brave that lord;
And show some power o'er my ingrateful friends;
The devil, ay, the devil; what music's this? Music.
Descends it from the spheres?
Hangs it in the air?
Or issues it from hell? Come where it can
I will attend the novel.
sp.stage: Enter an antic habited in parchment indentures, bills, bonds, wax seals, and Pen, and inkhorns, on his breast writ, I am a scrivener. Dances a strain, and stands right before him.
sp.l: Ha? What art thou? I am a scrivener.the devil thou art.
sp.stage: Enter dancing another strain, one written o'er his breast,
sp.l: I am a knave. Stands as the other.
Why pointest thou to thy breast, I am a knave?
The proverb were not true else, for it says, the devil's a knave.
Enter a third with this word,I am a prodigal.
I am am a prodigal? I was indeed, and thou dost well to
Mock me; what fury sends hell next?
Enter a fourth with this,I am a beggar.
I am a beggar? yes, I am indeed,
But how the devil cam'st thou by my style.
Enter a fifth with this,I am a Puritan.
I am a Puritan? one that will eat no pork,
Doth use to shut his shop on Saterdayes,
And open them on Sundays: a Familist;
And one of the arch limbs of Belzebub,
A Jewish christian, and a christian Jew;
Now fire on thy sweet soul.
Enter a sixth with this,I am a whore.
I am a whore? yes, and a hot one too,
And hadst a helping hand in my confusion:
Now the same blessing on thee.
sp.stage: Enter a seventh with money bags, and this motto,
sp.l: I am an usurer.
I am an usurer, Satan's eldest son,
And heir to all his torments; thou hast swallowed
Young heirs, and hell must one day swallow thee.
Enter an eighth with this,I am a devil.
I am a devil? good, 'tis the black lad I so long wished to meet.
sp.stage: The dance continued, in the conclusion whereof, etc.
sp.l: The scrivener bears away the knave; good moral.
The prodigal the beggar; ever so;
The Familist the strumpet, not amiss;
O but the usurer still the devil and all,
whom I so fain would speak with; Belzebub,
If thou hast any sufferance here on earth,
Or limited power o'er man, once more appear
And offer me free language. Enter the devil like a gentleman, with glass eyes.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: The devil Belzebub, whom thou so late so loud didst invocate

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: How cam'st thou by this shape of gentleman?

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: As if all habits, fashions, and attires
Were not with me familiar? I sometimes
Into a lawyer can transform myself
To delay causes; then to a divine,
To devise new sects, schisms, and heresies:
To a tailor for new fashions: to a sempster,
I was first father for this yellow sterch,
Which did succeed the blue; to a feather-maker
For gentlewoman's fans, men's sprigs, and falls;
Sometimes I am a page, and daily attend
Upon my lords luxurious appetites:
Then can I play the master, knight, and lord,
And then coin strange varieties of riots,
Lusts, and excesses, never heard before.
Indeed, what can I not?

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: It never was my study, and of all things I only except that.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Yes, both on soul and body, where I am suffered.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: How then came all those pulpit heresies
That have with Christians, Christians set at odds?
I read to that great doctor Arius,
That poisoned three parts of the Christian world;
There's not a sectary, nor a schismatic,
To whom I am not tutor.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Can I then task thee in nothing?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Thou canst not â€” stay?
Thou canst not change affection, nor invert the passions of
The soul; turn hate to love, and love to hate.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Tush, that with ease I can.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: And revenge wrongs?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: One thing more, and I conclude;
Thou canst not raise a man of desperate hopes
To a full furnished palm; to pay his debts,
And to give freely where he please to distribute?

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Am I not titled prince of all the world?
And lies there that in this great universe
Excepted from my large dominion?
Am I not Mammon too, the god of gold,
Sovereign of all exchequers, treasures, mints,
And those rich mines that set the world at odds?
In search of which men hazard dangerous seas,
Expose them to diseases, and strange climates,
Above their natures: gold? I am father of it,
And have it in abundance.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Then from can, I come to will; wilt thou, great
Belzebub, so much of thy huge surplusage make mine
As shall do all that I have here proposed?

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: That when thy wishes have attained effect,
Thou art full handled, hast paid all thy debts,
And nothing owest to any, I may then
Most freely claim thy soul.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Come, strike me luck; it is a bargain:
We shall need no witness.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Thy conscience is a thousand, that shall serve;
Let me but have't confirmed beneath thy hand,
And my exchequer's open.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: 'Tis confirmed; I see the devil yet hath more honesty
Then hath his son, the usurer; for to him
A man may pawn his soul a thousand times
Ere he can get a penny: but the father's,
Of a far more free nature.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Come, withdraw, we'll
Have't confirmed within. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4. Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter lord Skales, Treatwell, 2. Gentlemen, Geoffrey, and mistress changeable.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: But is your house so haunted?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: How long hath it been so?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Ten days, no more,
Part of that time that Slightall hath been mad,
My daughter passed her senses.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: No, only one by chamber stands remote,
And in that after midnight there's a noise,
That troubles the whole house of howlings, shrieks,
Fireworks and crackers, as if the great squib-maker
Were new come from beyond sea.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Only my desperate husband, who, one night,
Would be so foolish venturous as lodge there,
But did return so frighted, told such wonders,
Still fright me to remember.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: 'Tis most strange: sure 'tis some vexed spirit that hath
Deceased of late from out the house: who died last in that chamber?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Heaven rest her soul, my mother.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Perhaps hers; who having hid some treasure in her
Life time must, till that be discovered, walk of force,
The like I have read in legends.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: It hath been common, though not in these days
Frequent, might I advise, I would seek out for some
Religious man to exorcise the spirit, and by that means
To banish thence the vision.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Counselled well; there are in town 4. several sorts of friars, white and black friars, grey friars and crutched friars.

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.l: Good, you call to my remembrance
Among them, one expert in the art of necromancy,
His name friar John, whom Islington hath
Made famous through London.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: Him I saw but now cross by the door.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Good Geoffrey find him out, and gently entreat him hither,
But acquaint him not with the cause.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: But hath he done such strange things?

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.l: Wondrous sir; he can transshape his spirits, if fame
lie not, into what form he please, to imitate me,
Or personate you; he could produce a devil
In shape of this good ancient gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.l: H'hath done't in habit of a constable,
And may do't in a gentlewoman's; for his commons
In the friars he cares not, he can for a need
Conjure his bread from Spain, from France his wine,
His diet from the utmost of the earth,
Thus hath his fame given out.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.p: Would we might see him to make proof of his cunning.

div.stage: Enter changeable, and his daughter Anne.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: And as I told thee Nan, be swayed by me,
I'll make him thine, employ my industry,
Counsel and pains, to wean him by degrees
From his wild course of desperate melancholy:
I'll seek him out, persuade him, lay thy love
As open as the midday: hope in me
And doubt not to prevail.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Thou knowest he loves me; I was still his friend,
And friend with friend what cannot he perform?
Make thyself mine, I'll cross thy mother's workings,
And fool that lords attempts; only be you of a more
Temperate humour, and more stayed, observing but what I
Shall project for you, and doubt not my performance.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You in all things
Have proved yourself a father: I'll henceforth
Strive to express a daughter.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Here's now my husband, he can speak it all.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But ere I question that, of you, fair mistress,
Let me be first resolved; is your brain yet
In a more settled temper?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Sir, it is; methinks I am new wakened from a
Dream, in which I long have slumbering lost myself.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I am, thank heaven, and my good
Father's counsel and advice.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: I held it wife, a deed of charity, and did it for the lords sake.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, henceforth I shall observe you better.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You now have wreathed me with a crown of hopes.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Made me again thy mother, and this work,
Your ever patient and obedient wife.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Marry heaven continue it wife, 'tis but need;
In conscience thou hast been froward long enough.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: These things so well succeeding, pray resolve us
In what form doth this devil haunt your house.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: So I told you, sure your mothers.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Troth she was somewhat shrewish like my wife,
But yet I think not hers.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: This apparition was the full portrait of a young beauteous lady.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: A harmless spirit fashioned from the air,
And yet assuming substance, shape and form,
That where she loves, doth all the offices
Of a fair lady: can supply with gold.

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.p: And all things to man useful.

sp.speaker: Chan
sp.l: So I have heard; but this cannot be she,
For this had with her beauty so much terror,
So much affright and horror in her looks,
Such a confused noise, with hellish sounds
Able to drive the senses retrograde;
Turn reason into madness, and invert
Capacity to fury; that, I vow
I would not to be heir of all the world
Endure like night again. Enter Geoffrey and Friar John.

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.p: Here comes the friar, the man can best instruct us.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Hail gentlemen, this man that stands at livery
And saith he doth belong to a great lord.
Hath partly by entreats, part by command,
Enforced me from my meditations back
To know his lordship's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Welcome friar, 'tis told us thou canst exorcise a spirit,
we have employment for thee.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Expect you such things from religious men,
And of our holy order?

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.l: Come, we know you are an artist in that hidden skill,
