And have commerce with mighty Asterothe,
That great arch devil.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Now mercy heaven who hath seduced you thus?

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: Come, come we know it,
And this withal; in what men are most expect,
In that they are most dainty, and so you;
In dancers and musicians 'tis found true;
Of all men, where they are most excellent,
They are most curious to express their skill,
So no question, you.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Remember Islington, my host, my hostess, and the constable,
Should we be silent, every oyster-wife,
Fishwife, and those cry milk and oranges
Can speak of your rare supper; fie, friar John,
And so dainty to your friends?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Either I must take upon myself, and by some trick evade it,
Or else shame that which I have done before.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: As you would purchase us your lasting friends.

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: Or make us at our deaths,
Give legacies unto your holy convent.

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.p: Come, we know what you can do, good friar.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: What, you make me a conjurer?

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: A man of art, no more; so much we know you are.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: His house is haunted by a wicked spirit
Which we would have you by your art remove.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: To lodge one night within the chamber,
And know of it the cause of its disturbance,
Or what might be the will of the deceased,
Which known, and being performed, the troubled ghost
might rest in peace.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Lodge where the foul fiend walks?
A proper jest t'expose me to such danger,
So I might come to justify the proverb,
Where had the devil the friar, but where he was;
But I must face it out: pray gentlemen, which of you all
Hath seen that vision? in what shape walks it?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Like a woman sir, but with such horror
And astonishment, I tremble once to speak't.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: And I to hear't.
What a she devil now? for all the world
I would not once affront her; bring me hither
Ten thousand male fiends, I could charm their tongues
Before one female fury.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Sure this friar is wittily conceited?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Had it been great Belioth, Asteroth, or Belzebub,
I durst affront them, and confront them too,
O but the devil's dam; why against her
There is no prayer, no spell, no exorcism;
No circle that can hold her: but appeared she
Wrinkled in brow or fair and beautiful?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: As lovely to the view as flourishing may,
Clad in the pride of spring.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: So much the worse,
Well wot you that our order is by oath
Confined from any meeting with that sex,
Especially at midnight; and so late;
Scarce in the daytime durst I meet a face
Of such temptation, but in dead of rest
'Twould scandalize my order.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Press him not, if he be so precise.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Heaven's benison and mine light on you till I meet you next;
But to lie there where a she devil haunts,
(Less with my hosts by at Islington)
May the grand devil fetch me, bless you all. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Tush, scholars still are cowards, let him pass,
Daughter, you still are mine?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Enough; will any of you gentlemen,
In that my last: night's lodging second me?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: 'Tis too full of terror; Geoffrey wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Offer myself to the devil before my time?
You might accuse my folly.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: It shall be then my care to find out one
To conjure down this spirit, and doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: So much for that: but mistress, what from me,
Except you to express my gratitude
For this so late a favour?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Only this; t'avoid all imputation fame may cast
Upon my honour touching Slightall's fall,
In which the world may think I had chief hand:
'Tis but to find him out, and on his poverty
Bestow some small relief.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Now as I live, I'll do't with a full and
Plenteous hand if that be all.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: I'll aid him in the search to make
That sweet conclusion.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: In the mean time 't shall be my providence
To have my house unhaunted; come my lord,
Lead you the way, my wife and I will follow.
Remember Nan. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. 4. Scaen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Roger.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Want whilst I have, or hear my pockets chide?
While his are silent? there's no justice in't:
And if he do while my exchequer lasts,
May I be held a proverb made to cast
In every false grooms teeth?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Upon my â€”

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: I will not trust to hearsay, let thine eyes
Proclaim what's written in this almanac,
If this be the set day.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: If't be not tendered then 'twixt sun and sun,
The mortgage is my own.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: If you have the conscience to take the forfeit.

sp.speaker: Use.
sp.l: Conscience? what in that is wanting he shall find
Made good in law.

div.stage: Enter Slightall gallant, and his page with moneybags.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I see the devil yet is good to some,
Though it repents me of the bargain sealed,
Yet am I glad and proud of my supply;
Which the more precious is, being infinite,
Not capable of end; for Mammon's treasure,
A prodigal hand may waste, but never consume.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: What sudden change is this? do my eyes mock me,
Or must I call him master?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Roger? A hand; I know thou art in want, as one some
Weeks that hath been out of service, take that gold
And spend it freely, when thou wantest here's more.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: And you are both in cash and sense likewise?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Why man, 'tis want of money makes men mad,
For that disease here's physic: honest Hodge,
Go thou and summon all my creditors,
Leave not a man to whom I owe, uncalled,
And pay them to the utmost they demand;
Be so far from bating of the principal,
As pay them all arrearages; 'tis our will
And do thou see't performed.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: What's that to thee? have we not here to do't?
Those debts that reckoned were mere desperate
First see discharged, unless some certain mortgage tied to a day.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Monsieur damnation? what, are you so near?
I know you sir, a thousand pounds and th'use,
Tender the sum, there's gold, and bring me back
The mortgage of my manor.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: I'm undone then: no haste good
Master Slightall, why to morrrow,
Or the next day will serve, some fortnight hence,
Nay, were't a month, I could forbear the money.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Quindecem michaelis, you remember that,
I prithee see this man first satisfied,
And do't without delay: if he deny
The tender of't I'll have it done in court;
With such we must not dally, quick, good Hodge:
That once dispatched, affairs of greater consequence
Attend thy trust and care.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: If needs I will, we usurers are like women
Who conceive with great pleasure, and are delivered
With great pain; so we get our wealth with infinite joy â–ª
And part with the least of it with infinite torment.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: To any man that can but show my hand,
Or witness where I have but passed my word,
Pay ready down, about it, and return.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: And have we lived to see the golden age once more?
Now Geoffrey, if I meet you I dare affront you boldly.

div.stage: Exeunt. Manet Slightall.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: How want dejects, and plenty cherishes?
What a new change perceive I in myself?
Yet not so much in habit as in heart!
The sight of gold hath shaken off all those dumps,
Whose leaden weights were hung upon my soul,
To keep it down from mounting; and I now
Find in myself a free and dexterous spirit,
Uncapable of cloudy melancholy. Ent. Lo. Treatwell, and Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I must, as did my mistress late enjoin,
Pass in the search of this sad gentleman, and to
His low dejected poverty cast some few pieces.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: If his pockets lining suit but to the outside
Of his clothes, he hath small need of them.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: What, grown so brave? he hath sure lighted on some cheat?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: 'Twas her injunction, and doubtless
I'll accost him; save you sir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: I would be so, but 'tis not you can do't.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I understood that you were late in want?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Not of a wife; but for your lord ships courtesy
I had had one too many, thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: For another? no,
Now much good do't you with the thing you have,
I have no more to part with.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Leaving that; I understand you are a gentleman
Nobly derived; but withal, you're poor.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: You will not sell your lordship?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Why he that asks the question, ay, my lord;
If you will walk by land I'm your first man,
I'll bid as fair as any.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: A bankrupt idle fellow brave your lordship?
Beat him to's wits, or let me kick him for you.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Ha, what's that? who, Geoffrey Codpeice, John Boe peep,
Is't you that prate so freely? my young Judas,
Have you conspired against me?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Stay, first we will debate in friendly terms,
Before you grow to outrage.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Done most lordly; your tongue will grace you
Better than your sword, 'tis the most noble fashion.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I'll be brief, I understood your state was much
Decayed, which in my honour I commiserating,
My purpose was in some sort to relieve you;
And would you better understand yourself,
It might appear a noble courtesy.
Because it came so free and uncompelled

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Such as one neighbour to another doth
To get his wife with child, a courtesy, and so it fitly may
Be called because it brings him to his knees.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Still, still misprision; might I advise you, proffer
What you purpose, and if refused, so leave him.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Counselled well: there's twenty pieces for you.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: For a wife? Her ladyship is yours for naught already,
And should I sell her twice?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: This saucy fellow usurps upon our patience,
Which we'll punish be our strong hand.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: A punisher, my lord? what beg the beadle's office?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: I doubt his lord ships warrant is not currant, therefore I'll not obey.

div.stage: As they strive to oppress him, ent. Rog. they 2. beat of the other 3.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Sir, all's dispatched, but by my faith I lie,
Here's something here to do.
Why God a mercy master, I perceive
your spirits not all spent.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Thanks to thy sword, or I had been oppressed else.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: But how differed you? to be assailed by such a shameful odds.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: They scoffed at my supposed poverty,
And my great lord forsooth, as I had begged,
Would have bestowed his guerdon on my want,
Which taking in foul scorn, the valiant sir
Assailed me at these base advantages:
But hast thou done as I enjoined?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Most carefully; all's to the full dispatched.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: If with the devil â–ª I could dispense as well,
I should have ease within.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Ha, sirrah Geoffrey, I
Think you played at leap frog?

div.stage: Enter the devil, and claps Slightall on the shoulder.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Do not demand thy debt before the day;
Thy forfeit is not due yet.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: No such thing; the business that I come to treat with thee
Is of another nature.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Too hot for thy acquaintance, do not ask,
Attend me to my chamber, whether anon, I will not fail to come.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: Too hot, and why? he may be honest, but he hath the
Countenance of an old subtle knave; well, I'll attend you. Ex.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Have I not kept my word?

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Stored thee with all the supplements
Man's use can ask.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Nay, was not I assistant in this quarrel, prompting thy
Man to come to thy release, just at the instant danger:

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: His approach was fortunate and happy.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Then speak freely,
Didst ever in thy life time meet a friend,
Whose word, assured trust, and constancy
Could rank with mine in all things?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Never any; but what may this infer?

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Proof of thy gratitude, or to be termed unthankful.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Wilt thou in mere
sp.p: Requital of so many, do to me one fair office?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: First propose it, and then expect an answer.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: There's a house haunted with a she spirit, one of my
Servants, and kitchen maids in hell, employed by me
For some known causes, who hath played such pranks there
no man's so bold dares lodge within the room,
This bed would I have thee to undertake.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: To send me to hell before my day? your plot is too apparent.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Still amiss; have not I power o'er all my creatures there
To limit and command them? art not thou
One of our house by indenture? though to them
She appeared ghastly, horrid, and deformed,
To thee she shall seem fair and beautiful,
No whit inferior to that Grecian Queen,
That launched 1000. Ships from Aulis gulf,
And brought them to the fatal siege of Troy.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Make but this good, I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: And so confirm thee
A minion to the mighty Belzebub,
And great in our black kingdom. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene. 1.
div.stage: Enter lord, changables wife, and Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: But was he so perverse and peremptory?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: He braved necessity, and outfaced want,
And took my proffered largesse in such scorn,
As he had been some great King's treasurer;
My bounty he defied with shaking pockets,
The noise whereof deafened and seemed to drown
The sound of my despised charity;
Some pieces I would willingly have given.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Merely refused,
And with a haughty and contemplative smile,
Instead of grateful thanks, proudly demanded if I would
Sell my lordship.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: While I could limit patience I forbore,
To chastise him with an ungentle hand;
But when I found no bounds in his distaste,
But that it still exceeded law and compass,
I thought to chastise his ingratitude;
And did it with my sword.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: I think we made him fly, for I am sure some there
Gave shameful ground.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: But leaving that,
how doth my daughter relish you of late?
Do you not find her coming?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Affable, as any courteous maid alive can be,
To whom I did discover these proceedings,
Which she seemed well to relish.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Doubt not then, all will be to our wishes;
One thing only, which sads me when I think of't.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: To think my house should be so strangely troubled
In dead of night.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: And that I fear it is my mother's spirit,
Who for some unknown causes restless walks,
As one not sleeping in her quiet grave;
'Tis this that moves me deeply.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I have sent
To one friar Bernand, a religious man,
And tutor to friar John, to learn from him the depth of
This concealment; and see, in happy time
Treatwell's returnedEnt Treatwell.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Sir, I had conference with him.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: By no entreaty or persuasive skill,
Nay were he pressed by menace or command,
He vows to have no hand in these designs;
I could not make him think such things can be;
He counts them mere impostures, fallacies,
Or, let a man receive them at the best,
Illusions of the devil; that ghosts walk
He saith directly 'tis impossible,
And in that faith he'll die; further discourse
I could by no means get him listen to, but half displeased he left me.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: That's his faith, but we are forced to credit
Otherwise by lamentable proof. Ent. m. Changeable.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Here comes your husband, he hath perhaps some news

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I have been labouring, toiling and moiling,
To find the cause of this so strange distemperature,
Questioned divines, and talked with cunning men,
With fortune-tellers, skilled in palmistry,
Not a tained Gipsy can escape my search, but I with such
Have traffic.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Troth small, or none yet, most in this conclude,
That pretend judgement; that till we find some one
to lodge without companion in that bed,
And in the dead of darkness question it,
Why, to what end, and for what cause it walks,
The vision shall continue: this they said,
But none amongst them all so resolute as to
Attempt th'adventure.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Not so; for coming from the friary late,
I met a man by chance that crossed my way,
Whom rather too much spirit had possessed,
Or too much folly made mere desperate;
Would willingly attempt it, and indeed
He did entreat it of me as a suit.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Because he's mad:
For who of understanding, or of sense,
Would willingly confront great Belzebub,
Perhaps despair, distraction, discontent
Or fury hath possessed him; be't what will,
What's that to us? his is the certain danger,
Ours the assured gain.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: One like enough, were Hercules alive,
With him in Theseus' stead to enter hell;
A mad companion whom you all well know,
One that was once a suitor to my daughter.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Of all men living I am loath that he should lodge
Beneath my roof; were there none such he'd play the
Devil himself.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: But we have those
Within, can tame him were he twice so wild.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But he to be received? of all men living
I do not love that fellow.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: See your error,
What better way, more secret, and more safe
Can we devise to be revenged, than this?
To have him piecemeal torn by hags and fiends;
He hath no prayer to arm him 'gainst their assault,
His oaths will be assistant to their fury,
And further not repel it: you by this
Are from a rival freed; my daughter Nan,
From an importunate suitor, beggar too;
We all from a disturber, and a man
That wronged our common quiet.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: He says true sir,
let all your anger then conclude in this,
And bid the devil take him.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: I know not how you could dispose him better
And empty all your wishes.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Well, I am pleased,
Employ your best discretions.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Sick in her chamber, where she keeps her bed,
And dares not thence remove.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: The worse for her,
Yet for our purpose better, as it haps,
Because she shall not see him, nor he her;
Hark, there's one knocks, 'tis Slightall on my life;
Disperse I do entreat, I'll answer him. Within.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Where's this three-headed dog that keeps hell gates?
He knocks that fain would enter.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: 'Tis the same,
I know him by his roaring. Enter Slightall.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: If this, as many men give out, be hell,
Show me the master? he that keeps the house:
Pluto that great grim sir.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I am the lord
Of this poor manor; now, I cannot tell
By what hard fate distressed.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: O, you keep lodgings,
And as I understand, the devil here hath late took up his inn.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I would for one night be his chamber-fellow,
Shall I have entertainment, good mine host?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: I would not wish you sir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Wish me no wishes,
I am the knight adventurer that would do't:
One thing resolve me; hath the devil your guest
A horse in the stable?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Then make him pay for's bed; it is the custom
Of every inn through England.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Sir, I know you,
And ever wished you to your hearts desire,
How well you may remember; if forgotten,
In you 'tis error, and no fault in me.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Which love I thus have studied to requite,
To conjure hence your devil; how appears it?
In feminine shape?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: But not like madam Proserpine your wife?
No shape else can affright me.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I must confess
A devil of her tongue, but no way else sir.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: There

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Command me two fair tapers, that may last
and burn out this night's hell.

sp.speaker: Sl
sp.l: Those, my good sword, this book, and my bold heart
Are guards sufficient 'gainst a thousand shadows
Of no corporeal essence capable.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Some wine too, I entreat,
'Tis the best armour to a fainting soul,
And then no further trouble.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Whom am I to encounter? singly too?
Without a second? spirits, or phantasms?
Ghosts being, or imaginary dreams?
Not in the comfortable day, and view
Of judging eyes, but in the solitude
Of melancholy darkness? I'll not think of't, before
I find the truth, or mockery. Ent. with wine, Chan.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Indeed I must thank you for't? indeed I am your man; now, if you please,
Leave me to my adventure.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Rest may your body,
And peace possess your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Whate'er betide me.
Good night to you: see the doors locked and bolted,
That's all I shall enjoin you; till we meet
A fair and prosperous morning: did I know
What object I should meet with, I could then
Fit me unto the plunge accordingly,
And arm me for the grapple; but of this
I nothing can conjecture: o but that parchment
By which I am obliged to pay a soul,
The memory of that is horrible,
And strikes me with affright: what can I guess,
But that this is my devil's stratagem,
To have his sergeant death arrest me here;
And bear me to that cursed dungeon, hell?
An usurer would do't; any fat sergeant
That looks as plump in cheeks as th'other lean;
Then why not these? their gain's but petty trash,
But these the precious riches of a soul;
Yet in these hellhounds have I greater trust
Than in those dogs of th'earth, for I am sure
The devil himself can be no usurer,
He is so free of his purse; and hitherto
Hath lent his money gratis: I'll to bed,
and yet I will not; I'm no whit dismayed,
Nor yet at peace within; disquieted
With sudden fears, nor yet well reconciled:
I'll try if I can sleep; and yet not so,
Lest I be taken napping; yet I'll throw me
Upon the bed and read.
sp.stage: Ent. devils dancing, with fire wokes, and crackers.
sp.l: Hey, heigh, the devil's dance, sure hell's broke loose?
And this is their Shrove Tuesday; horns upon you,
And that's the cuckold's curse; yet this was sport,
Though somewhat fearful: had they proffered violence,
This should have thrashed among them, but it seems
These were no quarrelling spirits; yet howsoe'er,
I am glad they are gone: what object shall be next?
Music? yet this sounds sweeter than the first,
For that was all of discords.
sp.stage: Ent. two maids with banquet and lights; after courtesies to him, they fetch in Anne, and place her at the table against him.
sp.l: What, in hell are there white devils, angels are
These of light, or but light angels? Banquet too?
And feast? the furies in the lower world
I thought till now had fed on hot meats all;
On parboiled murderers, usurers roasted flesh,
Whores cheeks for dainties, carbonadoed o'er
Red sulphurous gridirons, and a thousand such:
But what's she enters now? to whom the rest
Do such obeisance? place her in her state,
As if she were the Queen grim Pluto stole,
And great Alcides once redeemed from hell?
Be'st thou ghost, shadow, fury, fiend, or hag,
Introth thou art a fair one; in heaven's name
What art thou? speak, dost answer me in smiles?
Why dost thou beckon me? point to those shadows,
As were the meats essential! had I a stomach,
With thee I durst not eat: dost laugh at me?
O hadst thou but a substance to that presence
I'd dare on thee, wert thou th' infernal dam.
Temptation still? I'll think her what she seems,
For no affright can lodge in her fair look,
And venture somewhat near; she's left alone,
and single; I will to her, what would you have me
Sit there? I will; eat? but begin I'll do't:
Fain would I take her by the hand, but fear
Hers rather would melt mine, than melt in mine:
Why should my sense of touching thus turn coward?
My eyes being so valiant, can you speak?
O such a wife through all the world I'd wish,
That would be ever tongue-tied; reach your hand?
I would and gladly too; 'sfoot I will venture,
No danger, a white, soft, and delicate palm,
That nigh dissolves in touching: you feel well,
Sweet, can you kiss? most sweet and excellent;
Again, again; were there no worse in hell,
And this the place, here would I wish to dwell.
Nay you that can both touch and lip it too,
Sure can do something else: beest thou a Lamia,
Or incubus, thou canst not scape me so;
I have a spirit in me great as thine:
Thou'st boarded it, I'll see if thou canst bed,
And try if thou hast mettle to thy shape;
Dumb spirits cannot clamour out for help,
I'll now try masteries. Thundering and howling, ent. Chan. like the devil

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Hellish fiend thou liest;
But ere thou claimest that debt, show me that beauty
I am so much entranced with.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: 'Tis vanished into air, whence it was formed.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Great Belzebub, yet once more let me see't.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Not possible, until you meet in hell; so near
Thy fate, and cannot now the terror of that place
Cool thy hot courage? see the forfeiture,
And here I do arrest thee.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Angels bale me,
Or I am ever lost.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: That hand I cannot, yet be not judge and
Accuser too; I'll put my cause to censure.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: I am content, 'tis done; howe'er thy soul
I'm confident is won. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. 5. Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter usurer, and scrivener.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: O, curse on that supply that snatched from me
So rich a mortgage.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: You looked not in the almanac
For good and evil days.

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: Yes, but too late:
For when 'twas past, I counselled with the day.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: And pray what was the motto.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Alas poor man, all to no purpose, be better advised,
Or it may be, kept out of his clutches; these, if we may
Believe th'astronomer, are ominous days.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Nihil in bag? A scurvy critical emblem,
Presaging empty pockets, why no cutpurse
Will trade when that's in power; then why would you
Lend money in that unlucky hour?

sp.speaker: Usu.
sp.l: It shall be a warning to me: in th'mean time
Would it were razed out of the calendar quite,
It is a day prodigious. Enter changeable and Slightall.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: If I can prove that all thy debts be paid
Thou art my own, was't not, and speak thy conscience,
Our joint condition?

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: That usurer's one of thy main creditors,
But when thou wast so free to pay thy debts, thou never
Dreamest of thy forfeit; propose to him thy question.

sp.speaker: Sl
sp.l: And I will, I bid thee that thy money
Never shall do, save thee.

sp.speaker: Usurer
sp.l: Beshrew you sir, you made me start,
What is your will with me?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I speak to thee
As to the drawer at the vintner's bar:
What is all paid?

sp.speaker: Usurer
sp.l: And like the bar-boy I
When you bring ready money, and keep touch
All's paid sir, and you're welcome.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: What's he that looks so ghastly?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: My pen and inkhorn bless me.

sp.speaker: Usurer
sp.l: All those crosses that I have figured on the
Princes coin, stand still betwixt me and danger,

div.stage: Exeunt Usu. and Scri.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: These are discharged, what refuge hast thou now?
Nay bring me unto all thy creditors;
I'll prove thy debts discharged.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I pray how many
of our best London gallants that hope heaven,
Can say the like? merit I hell for that?

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: But I must have my bargain.

div.stage: Enter two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Hast thou not owed to these?

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Resolve me friends, as you are gentlemen,
In what known sums did this man stand engaged to
Each of you?

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: I know not why you ask sir,
But the time was he ought me some few pieces,
I thought them desperate once, but nobly, since
He to the full hath seen me satisfied.

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.l: I never met with a more generous debtor,
I only trusted him with some few sums,
And he hath paid me use and principal,
A thing I never expected.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: That's all gentlemen â€” morrow

sp.speaker: Gen. 1.
sp.l: The like to you; I wonder what the devil
Slightall ails, he looks so strangely on us?

sp.speaker: Gen. 2.
sp.p: Sparks no doubt, of his first madness. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Do but name the man, to whom thou canst appeal.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I must confess I'm gone by th'common law,
The chancery too, because of thee, my conscience,
If to any, I appeal to the church.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: To any reverent father. Ent. Friar. Ber. and Friar John.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Then to these, to both, or either, freely take thy choice.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Holy friar Bernard then, my parting breath
Could not desire a better confessor.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: Read there, and tell me what thou think'st of that.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Give me but leave to take my second eyes,
I will resolve you presently.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: In th'interim, what's the best news in the parish?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I'll tell thee all I know,
We are better to the suburbs than they planted
Within the city; thereon holy days
The tavern doors are ever shut till six,
Else is the vintner fined; but there where we
Keep rendezvous may be let in at three, and never stir
The informers.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ten thousand creeds, as many paternosters,
Ave Maries stand between me and harm.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: In these conditions, I like a cunning lawyer find a
Clause to cheat the devil, and to save a soul;
Be'st thou the greatest fell with Lucifer,
Nay he himself, I now am armed for thee: what claimest
Thou of this man?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: By help of heaven I shall: this deed thus runs;
When all his creditors are satisfied,
His bonds discharged and cancelled, debts full paid,
His mortgages called in, his words redeemed,
This bond is then in virtue; not till then.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: All this I grant, and call to witness none
Save his own conscience; art thou not at freedom,
And clear from all the world?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Most true, I am,
Nor can I name that party under heaven
To whom I owe one farthing; a brass token
Will cancel all my scores.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What were the sums for which he stood engaged?

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Some fifteen thousand pounds, which I have paid,
And now the man owes nothing; therefore duly I
Claim both soul and body.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Both are quit,
As thou thyself shalt to thy grief confess;
For I will prove him more indebted now
Than e'er he was before.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: To thee,
Whom till he have discharged the utmost penny,
The bond's of no effect.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: The devil hath bragged he hath caught many a friar,
Now one hath caught the devil.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Yes, till thou payest him all his money down,
Which when thou dost thou'rt worthy to be damned.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Insert but that condition 'mongst the rest,
And I'll again subscribe; gramercy friar.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Nay then I see vainly we devils stand against the
Church, they have still the upper hand,
I yield me vanquished; in the mean time friar read
And conceal. Gives him another paper to read.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: What, by a quid d it freed? by a quirk in the law? by
This I see the devil's no good lawyer: give me my deed,
That I may see it cancelled and undone:
I'll tear it small as atoms, that no memory
Of the least letter be reserved as witness
Against my soul when I shall resurvive;
Nor shall I be at patience till I see
This parchment ashes, and this horrid writ
Dissolved to smoke and air.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: Yet for my love,
For all the good thou hast received by me,
For all my cost and charges, large expense,
As I acquit thee truly, so thou freely
Lend me thine ear.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Thy bounty hath deserved it â–ª
To save a soul I know no scrivener here
That would not only lend but give an ear.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am informed to th'full; if this be true,
Devil, th' art honest, and shalt have thy due:
Associate me friar John.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: With all my heart,
If this be Asteroth I so late invoked, I never shall desire
His company, but on an empty stomach. Ex. friars.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: And shall I meet her there?

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.l: And enjoy her to:
Do thou but hazard as thou didst before
And doubt not, she's thine own.

sp.speaker: Devil
sp.p: As a contracted bride and bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: No difference in her shape and ornament?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Thou canst do much with me, nor do I
Know beyond what bounds thy credence to extend: thou
Mayest prove false, but thou'st been yet my friend. Exeunt all.

div.head: Act. 5. Scaen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Anne in bed, mistress changeable, lord Skales, Treatwell and Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Let him stay,
Death's image cannot show so ghastly to me
As would the shape of doctor, I'll have none.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: If he come
Good faith I'll live no longer.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Sooth her up,
Or she will grow to frenzy.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Sick, o sick at heart, and you keep such a buzzing
In my ears, that I can take no rest;
Would you would leave me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: From whom, if't
Be his will, the lord deliver me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Your absence,
mother, and yours, and all of you; I am but dead
Unless you give me rest; o sick, sick, sick,
Your tongues like untuned bells, sound in my ears,
Nothing but grave and Church-yard.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Whom wilt have
To watch with thee all night?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: None but my father,
All tongues are noise and discords saving his;
But his like charming music, quietly
Summons my eyes to rest; and could I sleep once
I hope I should be better, o.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I shall disclaim all friendship with that tongue
That speaks another syllable; this prating
It strikes quite through my head, and makes it beat
As it would fall in pieces.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Mother, you talk of silence, and yet speak; how can that be?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: If you were sick at heart as I, you'd
Say mum were a word, mum sounds to me, being sick,
Loud as a cannon; why so? I thank you all, indeed you
Do me now a wondrous kindness; I pray, pray for me, I
Shall be well at midnight, well at heart;
And at head too I hope: and mother, nay reply not,
I'm like the man that could endure no noise
In'th silent woman, answer all in signs;
Mother I hope ere morning I shall find
Some more hearts ease; remember when you see't,
I told you of't before hand: I would sleep:
Hand in my bed, I'll turn to the wall, and try if I can
Sleep, so good night all. The bed pulled in

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: So, softly as you can; some little rest
Will bring her to her temper, for this night
We will commit her to her father's charge, since she so
Much desires it.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Any thing to give her least content.

div.stage: Enter old changeable and Roger.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Thou knowest my mind, what thou hast undertook
Manage with good discretion.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: 'Tis as safe
Here in my breast as under bolts and locks,
The cunningest picklock tongue that ever spoke
Shall turn these springs to open them; farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Farewell good Roger, but no word to 'Your master
Of what I have revealed thee kept from him.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: As I would do a kindness, lay't in me,
from my old fellow Geoffrey. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Now my lord; I am still labouring for the general
Good, to have my house at peace, and you content;
But wife, how is't with Nan?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Sir, wondrous ill,
She will endure no counsel, physic, language,
All tongues are clamour to her, saving yours,
Harsh as a black sant, or a grating wheel;
And I much fear without some providence, she scarce
Will live till morning.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But she entreats in midst of all extremes
That you would take the pains to watch with her,
No other she'll endure.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: And sir, I'll do't,
No other tongue this night shall trouble her, nor presence
Save my own; shall I entreat your lordship, you good
Wife, and those you think best to associate you,
To stand in sight of all such apparitions
As shall in this room be made visible?
My life shall for your safety be engaged, in it can be no
Danger.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: What assurance can you produce for that?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: The word and faith of some approved religious,
Who have promised, at my great intercession, that this
Night shall be the last of all my progidies
That thus afflict my house.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: I am but one and I myself will venture.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Faith
And I.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: I do not think wife but there will be visions
Worthy both sight and observation to;
What will you say if Slightall be this night
Contract to a she fury? but no words,
I'll not tell you all I know; he's passed his sense
And apt for any stratagem of hell: I am promised
Much fair hope; will you ascend and guide my lord to a
Convenient place, where you may view this object?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: In th'mean time, how will you dispose yourself?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: To watch with Nan,
And in her great despair to comfort her;
Naught but the dangerous sickness of my girl
Could keep me from you, but the hour draws on,
Which ghosts ever are tied to.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Maugre spirits, I'll
Once take spirit into me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: A woman lead? They ascend.
'Twere baseness not to follow.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: My girl's my
charge, she hath been ever so, and therefore ought
This night; and since one devil some
Few days since began to haunt my house
She never had peace of thought, health, nor content,
Or least essential comfort; which to compass,
All art, wit, learning, this night I'll implore
To drive him hence, shall haunt my house no more. Exit.
Thunder. Enter above lord, wife, Treatwell, and Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The larum's given;
For at that watch word still the ruffling noise begins.

div.stage: Enter friars, Bernard and John at several doors, as hallowing the room.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.p: My lord these friars I know.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But whether
They, or but their shadows by art magic raised we
Cannot yet presume.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: But this I'm sure.
They are exceeding like.

div.stage: Friar Bernard fetches in at his door Slightall, and Roger, Friar Io. at his, Anne and the devil.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: That can be none but Slightall.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: My lord see, my
Fellow roger's damned, for he's got in
Among the fiends and furies.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Were I not certain my daughter Nan were desperately
Sick, and kept both bed and chamber, I durst swear
That were my girl.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Is she not dead tonight , and
Now her ghost there walks?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: What might we
Think of't? the friars prepare for marriage; but what, he
Stands for the father, whom they beckon to, to give
Her hand to Slightall.

sp.speaker: Gef.
sp.l: Now I have't;
Upon my life the devil can be no better; she the illusive
Spirit by whom this room was haunted, contracted
Now unto yond desperate ruffian.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But this troubles me, the fury should assume no other
Shape but her fair angel beauty.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Even for that, great reason too, would I could understand it.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Because he was enamoured first on her,
The more to tempt him, she assumed that shape,
whom else could she so fitly personate?
Nay go together, you have my consent,
I'll never forbid the banes.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Much joy unto you, good troth nor I.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: The devil give you good of't.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: And so the
Devil doth, for your kind consent my lord I thank you,
And gentle wife for yours.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And, next my father,
I hold it my fit duty, thanks to both.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Let me leap down the next way, for the contract
I vow to break.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.l: But mistress, that's the next way
To break your neck, and keep the contract firm;
The staircase will do better.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Fooled and deluded? give me way my lord,
For I will down among them.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Hie to shelter, for there's a storm coming.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: That you are man, this woman, I am rapt
And ecstasied in brain, but cannot yet
Unwrap my senses from this wondrous maze;
This sudden light of knowledge so much dazzles,
That in my judgement I am blinded quite,
And know not how to free me.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: That anon, my daughter making known your
Deep despair, your help I studied both of purse and brain,
And fearing a lost soul, I then turned devil,
To prove your better angel; talk with her,
For I must arm for thunder.

div.stage: Enter lord, wife, Treatwell, and Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Was this a marriage in the devil's name?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Yes, and his dam in presence; she looked on.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Were you sick with a vengeance?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: But I told you I should be well by midnight;
So good mother I feel myself I am well, never better

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Shall I be plain, my lord? I crave your pardon,
Wife, for your rage I am armed, yes,
If thou couldst encounter with
flesh-hooks, and with firebrands; for I tell thee
I am practised in the devil: but to you, my lord,
I passed my faith unto this gentleman,
Had it been done to you I never had broke it.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Sir you speak nobly;
What must be, must be: it is in the will of heaven,
And I am well pleased with it.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: And am I overreached? well Slightall,
My blessing on thee, she's thine.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Mother, my knee in duty bows thus low:
My lord, your hand, I hope no
Malice harbours in your heart.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Sir I do not; and all I hope are pleased.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: If these be so, we then are happy,
We are new wedded, you are our chief guest,
Though once my rival, now you are my friend:
My fortune thus all malice hath defeated,
And by a new trick the grand devil cheated.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes.
